note_text:
Admission Date:  [**2116-7-5**]     Discharge Date:  [**2116-7-11**]

Date of Birth:   [**2081-8-30**]     Sex:  F

Service:  Trauma

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  Ms. [**Known lastname 42020**] is an unfortunate
34-year-old female that sustained a motor vehicle accident on
the [**State 350**] Pike.  The patient was an unrestrained
passenger, and she was expelled out of the car resulting in
the car landing on top of her.  This is how the patient was
found by the paramedics.  Having a difficult time with the
exhortation process.

She was med-flighted to the [**Hospital1 188**] with [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 2611**] Coma Scale of 15.  She was complaining
of right pelvic pain.  Upon arrival, and after the initial
trauma survey was done, there were no other obvious injuries
but she was somehow tachycardic with a blood pressure in the
100s.  For this reason, she was aggressively resuscitated in
the trauma bay.

Once her vital signs were stable, she was taken to the CAT
scanner for a CT of her head, abdomen, and pelvis.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:   Past medical history was
noncontributory.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:   She had no surgery before.

ALLERGIES:  She had no known drug allergies.

MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION:  The patient was not taking any
medications.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  She is married.  Portuguese-speaking.  She
has two children.  She denied any ethanol, tobacco, or
intravenous drug abuse.

RADIOLOGY/IMAGING:   The head CT was negative as well as the
initial trauma series.

A chest CT revealed lung edema, especially on the dependent
lower part.  There was some amount of free fluid within the
abdomen.  There were no solid abdominal organ lesions.  No
free air was identified.  The free fluid was low-density, and
it was unclear what the etiology or origin of it was.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  Since the patient still remained
tachycardic, and there was a significant amount of lung
edema, the patient was returned to the trauma bay where she
was intubated, and a diagnostic peritoneal lavage was
performed.  The diagnostic peritoneal lavage was negative,
and the patient was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit to
continue her monitoring for frequent neurologic checks.

Overnight, she remained hemodynamically stable, and she was
extubated without any problems the next morning.  A repeat
chest x-ray showed resolving resolution of her lung edema.

That day, upon neurologic examination and evaluation, she was
again complaining of numbness of her right lower extremity.
The numbness extended from her ankle all the way up to her
proximal thigh anteriorly only.

A Neurology consultation was obtained, and they suggested
that this was plexopathy probably related to the compression
that she suffered underneath the car from her accident.  The
recommendation at that time was to follow up with them in one
month, and that this would progressively improve.

After two days in the unit, Ms. [**Known lastname 42020**] was stable enough
to be transferred to the floor on CC6.  She continued to
ambulate with the help of Physical Therapy and the nursing
staff.  Physical Therapy noted that she had a mild foot drop
upon ambulation.  Once again, after we thoroughly evaluated
the patient, she was able dorsiflex her right foot, having
motor function totally preserved.  She continued to complain
of numbness anteriorly in the region previously described.

By hospital days five and six, she remarkably improved, being
able to ambulate almost independently with the help of
Physical Therapy and the nursing staff.

By hospital day seven, she was tolerating a good diet, and a
Physical Therapy consultation for home services was obtained.

CONDITION AT DISCHARGE:   She was discharged from the
hospital on [**2116-7-12**] in good condition and on oral pain
medication.

DISCHARGE FOLLOWUP:  She was instructed to follow up with the
[**Hospital 878**] Clinic in one month and also to make a follow-up
appointment in the Trauma Clinic so we could see her wound.





                          [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **], M.D.  [**MD Number(1) 11889**]
